description.narrative: SUMMARY: In response to the humanitarian situation, Plan International, in collaboration with the Dutch Relief Alliance funded by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, leads the Burkina Faso JR.

The overarching objective of the JR is to provide 104.851 affected people with life-saving and life-sustaining goods and services. The DRA partners have designed their response based on needs and gaps in line with cluster recommendations, their technical expertise and complementarity with other interventions to maximize impact. The response is a multi-sector approach with holistic WASH, Health, Food Security and Livelihoods (FSL), and Protection programs supported by MPC. The response will contribute amongst others to the following objectives from the HRP (April, 2021):
SO1: By 2021, 1.3 million people receive emergency humanitarian assistance to reduce morbidity and mortality, alleviate suffering and strengthen the protection of civilians. SO2: Improved access to services for target population. SO3: By 2021, protection needs and respect for human rights of 2 million women, men, girls, boys and people living with disabilities affected by the crisis will be ensured.

The past two years have seen a sharp deterioration in the security situation across Burkina Faso’s northern and eastern regions (large parts of the East, Central North, North, Sahel and Boucle du Mouhoun regions) due to the presence of non-state armed groups – many with cross-border ties to extremists groups or movements in neighboring Mali and Niger (OCHA Situation Report, November 2021). Armed violence has caused massive population displacements, while civilians are increasingly targeted. A state of emergency remains in 14 out of the 45 provinces. FEWS NET (October 2021) reports that the third quarter of 2021 saw the number of security incidents in the north and east more than double compared to the same period in 2020 (Figure 1). The number of security incidents links up with the increasing number of people in need and/or food insecure. Recent REACH monitoring confirms that insecurity (presence of armed groups / community tensions) remained the main push factor that forced IDPs to flee their home locality. The security incidents clearly are the trigger for people to leave their homes and result in a steadily increasing number of displaced.

This JR prioritizes IDPs fleeing conflict, especially newly displaced people. Priority is given to crisis-affected vulnerable families with pre-existing vulnerabilities before the crisis, and who have suffered human loss, loss of assets or livelihoods. Special attention will be given to displaced households in overpopulated temporary resettlement camps.
